A big reason for that was the marketing.

Was it a new console?
Was it an add-on for the existing Wii?

And the implementation of the

For starters, it seemed

The Nintendo DS is another example

But don't get me wrong, after eight years,

and a massive catalog of games.

However, when it first launched,
it was a pretty hard sell.
The problem was of true 3D gaming,

without the need for any type

It was pretty much just a gimmick,

The 3D imagery was blurry,

it made the already low-resolution

Personally, I always left it off.
In fact, that's one of the reasons why,

if I'm ever going to play

it was just a very expensive DS.

The Virtual Boy.

In fact, the graphics were closer

This just had red and black.

So you get red and black

Now, VR today, even
with its high resolution

and high frame rates, can
still make people nauseous,

blurred vision, headaches, and nausea
to the point where several games even came

with an option to automatically

Now, unsurprisingly, a
console with subpar graphics

and outdated games didn't

it would make you sick.

it would just give you,

to unlocking something
already programmed to the game.

Like, I mean, it was properly slow.

most people just know

Now, the Power Glove was

Nintendo's touted that after

Except, none of that worked, like, at all.

Nintendo was criticized for

something I feel like my mom

So the DD was actually

Nintendo opted to use magnetic
CDs instead of optical,

that much more storage

In their first attempt

Very similar to the Wii U.

Final Fantasy Crystal
